entry.title: ü¶ô Ollama - beyond the surface (unpolished notes)
entry.content:
If you are in the LLM game, chances are you‚Äôve come across Ollama. These days I am doing a deep dive on it (for something that will be announced soon).

The official project description is ‚ÄúGet up and running with large language models locally‚Äù.

I‚Äôd go a step further: it‚Äôs akin to Docker for LLMs.

  • you can quickly run models on different operating systems
  • you can package models and templates for reproducible runs (using a Modelfile)

Let‚Äôs delve a bit deeper üïµÔ∏è

  • locally means your cheap laptop (no GPU for LLM inference), your Mac or even a server located anywhere

  • llama.cpp popularized the idea of running LLMs on a standard laptop and introduced the GGUF quantized format, to perform inference on CPU (+GPU if available). Ollama abstracts away the complexity of installing llama.cpp on different platforms.

    Using GGUF models in Ollama is as simple as typing ollama run llama2 or ollama run llama2:7b-text-q5_K_M (to specify quantization options).

  • the goal of Ollama is to easily run LLMs everywhere. In contrast, vLLM and TGI are robust solutions for LLM inference/serving on GPUs. Although the goals are quite different, I can see some overlap in the future, if Ollama becomes one of the default ways for running open-source language models.
